Description: Acanthosis nigricans is a skin condition characterised by a velvety papillomatous overgrowth of the epidermis. Darkening and thickening (hyperkeratosis) of the skin occurs mainly in the flexural areas,particularly the axillae,groins,inframammary regions,and the neck. Acanthosis nigricans is usually a sign of an underlying condition or disease,such as obesity or diabetes (benign). Its presence as a sign of internal malignancy is very rare.
Diagnosis: The diagnosis is made clinically,including a thorough history of current and past medical conditions,family history,and medications.If there is diagnostic uncertainty,abiopsycan be sent forhistopathologicalanalysis and confirmation. Abrupt onset in a thin individual should alert the physician to the possibility of an underlying malignancy; prompting an appropriate history,examination,and investigations.
Differential Diagnosis: Confluent and reticulated papillomatosis: occurs more commonly in females with a mean age of 18–21 years. Reticulation is heterogenous instead of homogenous as seen in acanthosis nigricans. Pigmentation is not associated with peripheral reticulation in acanthosis nigricans.Erythrasma: characterized by well-demarcated red patches with possible scaling,found mainly in the intertriginous regions. A Wood lamp exam showing coral-red fluorescence is helpful in distinguishing it. Intertrigo: characterised by erythematous patches with possible pruritis and tenderness. It is nonspecific inflammation that is worsened by humidity. History of pruritus and morphology are helpful distinguishing features. Postinflammatory hyperpigmentation: this is localised and site-specific to the skin inflammation,and often there is a history of skin trauma or irritation. Tinea versicolor: hyperpigmented tinea versicolor presenting on the neck can be confused with acanthosis nigricans. Differentiation can be made by skin scale direct mycology.
Treatment: The mainstay treatment is to manage the underlying disease. Patient education is also an important component. General measures: Non-pharmacological treatment can include lifestyle modifications such as a establishing a healthy diet,increasing exercise to help attenuate insulin resistance and hyperinsulinemia. Metformin and rosiglitazone have been used to reduce insulin levels and moderately improve the lesions. Malignant acanthosis nigricans should be managed with careful workup and management of the malignancy. Cyproheptadine can aid in the regression of acanthosis nigricans associated with malignancy because it inhibits the release of tumour-produced substances. Withdrawal of the suspected drug can help in resolving drug-induced acanthosis nigricans. Syndromic acanthosis nigricans can be improved with treatment of underlying syndrome. For example,use of oral contraceptives for polycystic ovary syndrome. Treatment of acanthosis nigricans lesions can also be undertaken for cosmetic reasons. Pharmacological treatment modalities can include: Keratolytic agents: salicylic acid,glycolic acid,or trichloroacetic acid. Topical retinoids: adapalene gel,or tretinoin cream. Calcipotriol. Omega 3 fatty acids (fish oil). Podophyllin. Procedural modalities include: Psoralen plus UVA (PUVA). Dermabrasion. Long-pulsed alexandrite laser therapy.
Demographics: Acanthosis nigricans affects < 1% of Caucasians. In the United States,the estimated prevalence is 13% of African Americans,5% of Latinos,and 34% of Native Americans.
Gender: It affects both males and females
Age Group: Affects all ages,with people < 40 years old typically being more affected. Acanthosis nigricans was found in 18% of children and 19% of adults in a cross-sectional study (n=1730) in the United States.
Additional note: Those diagnosed with acanthosis nigricans were twice as likely to have type 2 diabetes than those without (35% vs. 17%). Rarely,there is a link with an internal malignancy. Patients with malignant acanthosis nigricans tend to be middle-aged,not obese,and lesions develop abruptly.
Cause: The exact cause is still unclear,however it is predominantly linked to states of insulin resistance where obesity,diabetes,or metabolic disorders (eg,metabolic syndrome,polycystic ovary syndrome,generalised lipodystrophy) co-exist. Insulin crosses the dermal-epidermal junction and,in high concentrations,can have growth-stimulating effects through its binding to type 1 insulin-like growth factor receptors (IGFRs) on keratinocytes. This stimulates the proliferation of these cells,leading to acanthosis nigricans.
Symptoms: Symmetric,thickened,brown,velvety patches and plaques of skin that appear: Most commonly in the intertriginous areas: axillae,groin,and back of the neck. On the nipples,areolae,vulva,and perineum in women. On the mucous membranes of the oral cavity,nasal and laryngeal mucosa and oesophagus; these lesions tend to be greater in extent and severity in malignant acanthosis nigricans Skin tags are common on cutaneous and mucosal surfaces Lesions may become macerated or malodorous Pruritus may be present and is very common in malignant acanthosis nigricans. The skin may appear darker and leathery in darker skin phenotypes. People with skin phototype IV have a higher frequency of acanthosis nigricans on the neck compared to those with skin phototypes II and III. There is a very high certainty of insulin resistance in people with light skin that have acanthosis nigricans. However,in people with skin of colour,acanthosis nigricans can be present without concurrent insulin resistance. Therefore,the skin phenotype influences the likelihood of acanthosis nigricans being a predictor of insulin resistance.
Complications: Cosmetic disfigurement. Psychological distress. Acanthosis nigricans is an independent risk factor for the presence of diabetes. Complications associated with underlying disease,for example,obesity-associated complications.
Outcomes: Outcomes depend on the cause. If the underlying etiology can be addressed eg,weight loss,then the acanthosis nigricans can resolve. Obesity,metabolic syndrome,and diabetes have deleterious effects on overall morbidity and mortality. Hereditary acanthosis may stabilise and even regress spontaneously in some cases. Malignant acanthosis nigricans is associated with a poorer prognosis (average survival time is 2 years) with early mortality often due to advanced cancer.
Preventive Measure: None

Description: Achenbach syndrome is a paroxysmal recurring painful bruising of the finger(s) or palm, not associated with serious underlying conditions.
Diagnosis: Achenbach syndrome is diagnosed clinically on the typical history and clinical presentation. Many patients have undergone exhaustive investigations for clotting disorders and ischaemic events,all of which are normal/negative.
Differential Diagnosis: Bruising due to clotting disorders or low platelet count. Capillary fragility due to vitamin C deficiency or amyloidosis. Vascular ischaemic events such as embolism or vascular spasm.
Treatment: Minimise known triggers. Analgesia if needed. Avoid aspirin and other non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. Elevation and cooling for swelling. Reassurance. There is no specific treatment.
Demographics: Although said to be rare,a study of 802 members of the general population aged 18 to 84 years in three regions of France found a prevalence of 12% in women and 1% of men. Achenbach syndrome has been reported in Caucasians and Asians. The discolouration may be less obvious in skin of colour.
Gender: reported in females
Age Group: median age of onset of 48–50 years (range 22–76)
Additional note: It is possibly more common in those with a history of Raynaud phenomenon and chilblains,however is not associated with smoking.
Cause: Achenbach syndrome is a subcutaneous bruise probably due to minor fragility of capillaries or a small vein in the palmar skin. Preceding minor trauma may be recalled in 30% of cases such as sweeping,handwashing of clothing,or cycling. There is no associated serious cause for easy bruising such as a clotting disorder or vascular abnormality.
Symptoms: Achenbach syndrome characteristically follows minor trauma,although this is often not recalled. Acute onset of pain followed minutes to hours later by discolouration,usually blue-purple.Palmar aspect of the dominant hand is the most common site. Second and third finger involvement is commonest,although any finger,toe,or palmar site can be affected. Sparing of the fingertip and nail bed is characteristic. Discolouration resolves spontaneously in 3–6 days (range 2–14 days),without going through the colour changes usually seen with a resolving bruise. Other — swelling; itch,burning or numbness; involvement of the dorsal digit; limited movement. Normal findings — radial and ulnar pulses; skin perfusion; skin temperature; nail bed capillaroscopy.
Complications: None
Outcomes: Achenbach syndrome is a benign condition with spontaneous resolution of lesions without sequelae. Episodes can recur with minor trauma,with an average frequency of recurrences of 1 per year.
Preventive Measure: "None"

Description: Acne is a common chronic disorder affecting the hair follicle and sebaceous gland,in which there is expansion and blockage of the follicle and inflammation. There are several variants.
Diagnosis: In most cases,tests are unnecessary. If features are atypical consider: Skin swabs for microscopy and culture Hormonal tests in females.
Differential Diagnosis: None
Treatment: Mild acne: Topical anti-acne agents,such as benzoyl peroxide,azelaic acid,and tretinoin or adapalene gel. New bioactive proteins may also prove successful. Low-dose combined oral contraceptive. Antiseptic or keratolytic washes containing salicylic acid. Light/laser therapy. Moderate acne: As for mild acne plus a tetracycline such as doxycycline 50–200 mg daily for 6 months or so. Erythromycin or trimethoprim if doxycycline intolerant. Antiandrogen therapy with long-term cyproterone acetate + ethinylestradiol or spironolactone may be considered in women not responding to low-dose combined oral contraceptive,particularly for women with polycystic ovaries. Isotretinoin is often used if acne is persistent or treatment-resistant. Severe acne: Referral to a dermatologist. If fever,arthralgia,bone pain,ulcerated or extensive skin lesions,blood count should be arranged and referral is urgent. Oral antibiotics are often used in higher doses than normal. Oral isotretinoin is usually recommended in suitable patients
Demographics: all races and ethnicities.
Gender: male and female
Age Group: It is prevalent in adolescents and young adults,with 85% of 16 to 18 year-olds affected. However,it may sometimes occur in children and adults of all ages.
Cause: Acne is due to a combination of factors. The exact mechanisms are not fully understood. Familial tendency,Endogenous and exogenous androgenic hormones,Acne bacterial,Innate immune activation with inflammatory mediators,Distension and occlusion of the hair follicles. Flares of acne can be provoked by: Polycystic ovarian disease. Drugs: steroids,hormones,anticonvulsants,epidermal growth factor receptor inhibitors and others. Application of occlusive cosmetics. High environmental humidity. Diet high in dairy products and high glycaemic foods.
Symptoms: Acne is often confined to the face but it may involve the neck,chest,and back. It is characterised by: Open and closed uninflamed comedones (blackheads and whiteheads). Inflamed papules and pustules. In severe acne,nodules and pseudocysts. Post-inflammatory erythematous or pigmented macules and scars. Adverse social and psychological effects. Severity is classified as mild,moderate,or severe.Mild acne: total lesion count <30. Moderate acne: total lesion count 30–125. Severe acne: total lesion count >125
Complications: None
Outcomes: Acne tends to improve after the age of 25 years but may persist,especially in females. Treatment with isotretinoin can lead to long-term remission in many patients.
Preventive Measure: None.

Description: Acral lentiginous melanoma (ALM) is a rare subtype of melanoma arising on the palms, soles, or under the nails. It is also known as acral melanoma. In early stages, ALM often appears as a dark brown or black macule with variegated colour, and can be nodular and ulcerated in advanced cases. ALM is slow-growing, and can take months to years to become invasive, ie, to grow beyond the basement membrane of the epidermis where it originates.
Diagnosis: The diagnosis is often made on clinical history and presentation, supported by dermoscopy. The following features are seen on dermoscopy for acral lentiginous melanoma (ALM): Parallel ridge pattern in early phases, Lack of features typical of acral naevi (fibrillary, lattice-like, parallel furrow patterns), Blotches, Asymmetry, Multiple colours, Diffuse pigmentation of the nail/stripes on the nail/nail ulceration. Definitive diagnosis is made with histopathology after excision or biopsy of the lesion. Staging is conducted as for any other cutaneous melanoma, with histopathological features such as Breslow depth, ulceration, and sentinel lymph node status. Histological features of ALM include an asymmetrical proliferation of melanocytes at the dermoepidermal junction.
Differential Diagnosis: The differential diagnosis for acral lentiginous melanoma is broad and includes the following: Acral naevi (either congenital or acquired), Trauma-related haemorrhage, Calcaneal petechiae (talon noir), Tinea nigra, Soil/stain. Of note, pigmented actinic keratoses and seborrhoeic keratoses do not occur on acral surfaces. Amelanocytic or hypomelanocytic lesions may mimic benign diseases such as warts, calluses, or benign tumours such as poromas.
Treatment: General measures: Education of health professionals and the public. Regular skin examinations. Multidisciplinary management with a podiatrist and occupational therapist where available. Specific measures: The mainstay of treatment for acral lentiginous melanoma (ALM) is wide local excision. Further treatment depends mainly on the Breslow thickness of the lesion. After initial excision biopsy, the radial excision margins, measured clinically from the edge of the melanoma, are: In-situ lesions: 0.5–1 cm margin, Breslow depth <1 mm: 1 cm margin, Breslow depth 1–2mm: 1–2 cm margin, Breslow depth >2mm: 2 cm margin. A skin graft or a flap may be needed to close the wound, or in some cases, partial amputation of a digit. If further treatment is required following excision, this may involve radiotherapy or immunotherapy.
Demographics: However, ALM is the most common subtype of melanoma in darker skinned populations, accounting for 40–60% of melanoma diagnoses in Asian and African-American ethnicities. It is the least common subtype of melanoma in Caucasian populations.
Gender: Males and females are equally affected.
Age Group: The incidence of ALM increases with age, with the average age of diagnosis being 63 years.
Additional note: Acral lentiginous melanoma (ALM) is the least common subtype of melanoma diagnosed overall, accounting for 2–3% of melanoma diagnoses. Females tend to be diagnosed earlier than males.
Cause: Acral lentiginous melanoma (ALM) usually arises de novo, but there are rare reports of acral melanoma arising from a pre-existing melanocytic naevus. The cause of ALM is not fully understood. Unlike other subtypes of melanoma, sun exposure does not appear to be a risk factor for its development, however, there are rare case reports demonstrating an ultraviolet signature as in other types of cutaneous melanoma. Suggested aetiologies of the cause for ALM include: Stress/shearing forces on the foot. Genetic mutations, including KIT, BRAF, NRAS, NF1, cyclin D1, CDKN2A, and MYC. The pathogenesis for melanoma includes overgrowth of melanocytes, the pigment-producing cells found deep in the epidermis.
Symptoms: In early stages, acral lentiginous melanoma (ALM) presents as a new light to dark brown pigmented macule on the palm, sole, or under a nail that follow the skin ridges. ALM is more commonly seen on the feet, possibly due to higher melanocyte density. Occasionally, ALM can present as an amelanotic or hypomelanotic lesion. These are difficult to diagnose as they often mimic benign diseases such as warts or calluses. Subungual melanoma arises from the nail matrix and usually presents as a longitudinal brown or black band in the fingernail or toenail. It may be associated with nail dystrophy. Involvement of the proximal nail fold (Hutchinson’s sign) is considered a clue to the diagnosis. Suspicious features for invasive melanoma: Nodular or darkly pigmented appearance. Ulceration. Pruritus. Increasing number of colours, particularly blue and black. Pigment extending from under the nail to beyond the nail fold. >7mm in size.
Complications: Clinical features do not vary significantly between skin types. It may be more difficult to visualise naevus structure on dermoscopy in darker skin types, appearing as a more homogenous colour. Complications of untreated disease: Progressive disease including distal metastasis. Complications of surgical management: Scarring, Skin contractures, Digital amputation, Phantom limb pain, Functional impairment, Loss of nail/s.
Outcomes: Compared with cutaneous melanoma, most studies suggest that acral lentiginous melanoma has a poorer prognosis, with diagnosis often occurring at a more advanced clinical stage. It is unclear if this is solely due to delay in ALM detection due to the difficulty in monitoring such sites (eg, soles of the feet), or is also a consequence of genetic and biological differences that promote tumour aggressiveness. The outcome of ALM depends primarily on Breslow thickness of the lesion and staging, including sentinel lymph node involvement. Other factors that may influence prognosis include age and gender.
Preventive Measure: While there are no known preventative strategies, regular skin checks and general sun protection are recommended. Any new lesions noted on the palms, soles, or under the nails should be reviewed by a medical professional.

Description: Actinic keratosis is a precancerous scaly spot found on sun-damaged skin, also known as solar keratosis. It may be considered an early form of cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (a keratinocyte cancer).
Diagnosis: Actinic keratosis is usually easy to diagnose clinically or by dermoscopy (see actinic keratosis dermoscopy). Occasionally, a biopsy is necessary, for example, to exclude SCC, or if treatment fails.
Differential Diagnosis: None
Treatment: Actinic keratoses are usually removed because they are unsightly or uncomfortable, or because of the risk that skin cancer may develop in them. The latter point is a matter of considerable debate, and the most robust studies (Cochrane review) did not find convincing evidence that AK treatment resulted in a prevention of invasive squamous cell carcinomas. Treatment of an actinic keratosis requires removal of the defective skin cells. Epidermis regenerates from surrounding or follicular keratinocytes that have escaped sun damage. Some AKs will resolve with the frequent and appropriate use of sunscreens. Tender, thickened, ulcerated, or enlarging actinic keratoses should be treated aggressively. Asymptomatic flat keratoses may not require active treatment but should be kept under observation. 1. Physical treatments: Physical treatments are used to destroy individual keratoses that are generally symptomatic or have a thick hard surface scale. The lesions may recur in time, in which case they may be retreated by the same or a different method. 2. Cryotherapy using liquid nitrogen: Liquid nitrogen spray is required to achieve adequate depth and duration of the freeze. This varies according to lesion location, width, and thickness. Healing varies from 5–10 days on the face, 3–4 weeks on the hands, and 6 weeks or longer on the legs. A light freeze for a superficial actinic keratosis usually leaves no mark, but longer freeze times result in hypopigmentation or scar. 3. Shave, curettage and electrocautery: Shave, curettage (scraping with a sharp instrument) and electrocautery (burning) may be necessary to remove a cutaneous horn or hypertrophic actinic keratosis. Healing of the wound takes several weeks or longer, depending on the body site. The specimen is sent for histological examination. 4. Excision: Excision ensures the actinic keratosis has been completely removed, which should be confirmed by pathology. The surgical wound is sutured (stitched). The sutures are removed after a few days, the time depending on the size and location of the lesion. The procedure leaves a permanent scar. 5. Field treatments: Creams are used to treat areas of sun damage and flat actinic keratoses, sometimes after physical treatments have been carried out. Field treatments are most effective on facial skin. Pretreatment with keratolytics (such as urea cream, salicylic acid ointment or topical retinoid), and thorough skin cleansing improves response rates. Results are variable and the course of treatment may need repeating from time to time. With the exception of diclofenac gel, field treatments all result in local inflammatory reactions such as redness, blistering and discomfort for a varying length of time. Diclofenac is more often used as an anti-inflammatory drug. A special gel formulation (3%) in a base containing sodium hyaluronate) is applied twice daily for 3 months, it is fairly well tolerated in the treatment of actinic keratoses, but less effective than the other options listed here. Piroxicam - similar to diclofenac. 5-Fluorouracil is a cytotoxic agent. The cream formulation is applied once or twice daily for 2 to 8 weeks. Its effect may be enhanced by calcipotriol ointment. 5-fluorouracil may be available as a combination product along with salicylic acid.Skin peels using trichloroacetic acid or Jessner solution. Imiquimod cream is an immune response modifier. It is applied 2 or 3 times weekly for 4 to 16 weeks. Photodynamic therapy (PDT) involves applying a photosensitiser (a porphyrin chemical such as methyl aminolevulinic acid) to the affected area prior to exposing it to a source of visible light. Tirbanibulin is a synthetic inhibitor of tubulin polymerisation and protein kinase signalling. This 5 day topical treatment received a product license in countries such as the USA, UK, and Germany in 2021. Oral retinoids have been used in organ transplant recipients and are shown to reduce the risk of SCC development in those with numerous AKs.
Demographics: Actinic keratoses affect people that have often lived in the tropics or subtropics and have predisposing factors such as: Other signs of photoageing skin. Fair skin with a history of sunburn. History of long hours spent outdoors for work or recreation. Defective immune system. However, even in temperate climates they may be common - in southern Ireland and North west England up to 25% of people aged 60 years and over have at least one.
Gender: Both male and female
Age Group: Around 60 years
Cause: Actinic keratoses are the result of abnormal skin cell development due to DNA damage by short wavelength UVB. They are more likely to appear if the immune function is poor, due to ageing, recent sun exposure, predisposing disease, or certain drugs.
Symptoms: Actinic keratosis may be solitary but there are often multiple keratoses. The appearance varies. A flat or thickened papule, or plaque. White or yellow; scaly, warty, or horny surface. Skin coloured, red, or pigmented. Tender or asymptomatic. They are sometimes graded according to their appearance: Grade 1: Mild pink or grey marks with slight scale and gritty to touch. Grade 2: Moderate thicker hyperkeratosis and easily detected. Grade 3: Severe hyperkeratotic thick keratin. Grade 4: Confluent areas several centimetres with a range of the above grades of AK. Actinic keratoses are very common on sites repeatedly exposed to the sun, especially the backs of the hands and the face, most often affecting the ears, nose, cheeks, upper lip, vermilion of the lower lip, temples, forehead, and balding scalp. In severely chronically sun-damaged individuals, they may also be found on the upper trunk, upper and lower limbs, and dorsum of feet.
Complications: The main concern is that actinic keratoses indicate an increased risk of developing cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma. It is rare for a solitary actinic keratosis to evolve to squamous cell carcinoma (SCC), but the risk of SCC occurring at some stage in a patient with more than 10 actinic keratoses is thought to be about 10 to 15%. A tender, thickened, ulcerated, or enlarging actinic keratosis is suspicious of evolution to SCC. Cutaneous horn may arise from an underlying actinic keratosis or SCC. Because they are sun damaged, people with actinic keratoses are also at risk of developing actinic cheilitis, basal cell carcinoma (BCC, which is more common than SCC), melanoma, and rare forms of skin cancer such as Merkel cell carcinoma.
Outcomes: Actinic keratoses may recur months or years after treatment. The same treatment can be repeated or another method used. Patients who have been treated for actinic keratoses are at risk of developing new keratoses. They are also at increased risk of other skin cancers, especially intraepidermal squamous cell carcinoma, invasive cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma, basal cell carcinoma and melanoma.
Preventive Measure: Actinic keratoses are prevented by strict sun protection. If already present, actinic keratoses may improve with a very high sun protection factor (50+) broad-spectrum sunscreen applied at least daily to affected areas, year-round. The number and severity of actinic keratoses can also be reduced by taking nicotinamide (vitamin B3) 500 mg twice daily.

Description: Allergic contact dermatitis is a form of dermatitis/eczema caused by an allergic reaction to a material, called an allergen, in contact with the skin. The allergen is harmless to people that are not allergic to it. Allergic contact dermatitis is also called contact allergy.
Diagnosis: Sometimes it is easy to recognize contact allergy and no specific tests are necessary. Taking a very good history including information on the work environment, hobbies, products in use at home and work, and sun exposure will enhance the chances of finding a diagnosis. The rash usually (but not always) completely clears up if the allergen is no longer in contact with the skin, but recurs even with slight contact with it again. The open application test is used to confirm contact allergy to a cosmetic, such as a moisturiser. The product under suspicion is applied several times daily for several days to a small area of sensitive skin. The inner aspect of the upper arm is suitable. Contact allergy is likely if dermatitis arises in the treated area. Dermatologists will perform patch tests in patients with suspected contact allergy, particularly if the reaction is severe, recurrent or chronic. The tests can identify the specific allergen causing the rash. Fungal scrapings of skin for microscopy and culture can exclude fungal infection. Dimethylgloxime test is available to ‘spot test’ if a product contains nickel.
Differential Diagnosis: Allergic contact dermatitis should be distinguished from: Irritant contact dermatitis, which is due to irritation or repetitive injury to the skin. Irritants include water, soaps, detergents, solvents, acids, alkalis, and friction. Irritant contact dermatitis may affect anyone, providing they have had enough exposure to the irritant, but those with atopic dermatitis are particularly sensitive. Most cases of hand dermatitis are due to contact with irritants. Irritant contact dermatitis can occur immediately after a single injury or develop slowly after repeated exposure to an irritant. Other forms of dermatitis, which may mimic allergic contact dermatitis. Contact urticaria, in which a rash appears within minutes of exposure and fades away within minutes to hours. The allergic reaction to latex is the best-known example of allergic contact urticaria. Fungal infections; tinea corporis may present as a unilateral rash.
Treatment: It is important to recognize how you are in contact with the responsible substance so that, where possible, you can avoid it. Find out precisely what you are allergic to by having comprehensive patch tests. Identify where the allergen is found, thus read labels of all products before use. Carefully study your environment to locate the allergen. Note: many chemicals have several names, and cross-reactions to similar chemicals with different names are common. Wear appropriate gloves to protect hands from touching materials to which you react and remove gloves in the appropriate way. Some chemicals will penetrate certain gloves; seek a safety expert's advice. Ask your dermatologist to help. Active dermatitis is usually treated with the following: Emollient creams, Topical steroids, Topical or oral antibiotics for secondary infection, Oral steroids, usually short courses, for severe cases, Phototherapy or photochemotherapy, Azathioprine, ciclosporin or another immunosuppressive agent, Tacrolimus ointment and pimecrolimus cream are immune-modulating calcineurin inhibitors and may prove helpful for allergic contact dermatitis.
Demographics: Allergic contact dermatitis is common in the general population and in specific employment groups. It is more common in women than men, mainly due to nickel allergy and, recently, to acrylate allergy associated with nail cosmetics. Many young children are also allergic to nickel. Contact allergy to topical antibiotics is common in patients over the age of 70 years old. Allergic contact dermatitis is especially common in metal workers, hairdressers, beauticians, healthcare workers, cleaners, painters, and florists.
Gender: Allergic contact dermatitis is more common in women than men, mainly due to nickel allergy and, recently, to acrylate allergy associated with nail cosmetics.
Age Group: Many young children are also allergic to nickel. Contact allergy to topical antibiotics is common in patients over the age of 70 years old.
Additional note: Patients with impaired barrier function of the skin are more prone to allergic contact dermatitis, e.g., patients with leg ulcers, perianal dermatitis, or chronic irritant contact dermatitis. Patients with atopic dermatitis associated with defective filaggrin (a structural protein in the stratum corneum) have a high risk of also developing allergic contact dermatitis.
Cause: Allergic contact dermatitis is a type 4 or delayed hypersensitivity reaction and occurs 48–72 hours after exposure to the allergen. The mechanism involves CD4+ T-lymphocytes, which recognize an antigen on the skin surface, releasing cytokines that activate the immune system and cause the dermatitis. Note: Contact allergy occurs predominantly from an allergen on the skin rather than from internal sources or food. Only a small number of people react to the specific allergen, which is harmless to those who are not allergic to it. They may have been in contact with the allergen for years without it causing dermatitis. Contact with tiny quantities of an allergen can induce dermatitis.
Symptoms: Allergic contact dermatitis arises some hours after contact with the responsible material. It settles down over some days providing the skin is no longer in contact with the allergen. Allergic contact dermatitis is generally confined to the site of contact with the allergen, but it may extend outside the contact area or become generalised. Transmission from the fingers can lead to dermatitis on the eyelids and genitals. Dermatitis is unlikely to be due to a specific allergen if the area of skin most in contact with that allergen is unaffected. The affected skin may be red and itchy, swollen and blistered, or dry and bumpy. Some typical examples of allergic contact dermatitis include: Eczema in the skin in contact with jewellery items, due to contact allergy to nickel, Reactions to fragrances in perfumes and household items, Eczema under adhesive plaster, due to contact allergy to rosin, Swelling and blistering of face and neck in reaction to permanent hair dye, due to allergy to paraphenylenediamine, Hand dermatitis caused by rubber accelerator chemicals used in the manufacture of rubber gloves, Itchy red face due to contact with methylisothiazolinone, a preservative in wash-off hair products and baby wipes, Fingertip dermatitis due to acrylates used in hair extensions and nail cosmetics, Reactions after dental implants containing acrylates, Localised blistering at the site of topical medications such as antibiotics, Swelling and blistering on exposed sites (e.g., face and hands) due to contact with plants such as poison ivy or, in New Zealand, the Japanese wax tree Toxicodendron succedaneum. There is a very long list of materials that have caused contact allergy in a small number of individuals.
Complications: Allergic contact dermatitis starts as a localized reaction to an allergen in contact with the skin, but severe reactions may generalize due to autoeczematisation and can lead to erythroderma. Ingestion of a contact allergen may rarely lead to baboon syndrome or generalised systemic contact dermatitis. Photoallergy: Sometimes contact allergy arises only after the skin has been exposed to ultraviolet light. The rash is confined to sun-exposed areas even though the allergen may have been in contact with covered areas. This is called photocontact dermatitis. Examples of photoallergy include: Dermatitis due to a sunscreen chemical, affecting the top but not the under the surface of the arm, Dermatitis of face, neck, arms, and hands due to antibacterial soap.
Outcomes: Contact allergy often persists lifelong so it is essential to identify the allergen and avoid touching it. Dermatitis may recur on re-exposure to the allergen. Some allergens are more difficult to avoid than others, with airborne allergens being a particular problem (e.g., epoxy resin, compositae pollen). The longer a person suffers from severe allergic contact dermatitis, the longer it will take to clear after the diagnosis is made and the cause detected. Dermatitis may clear up on avoidance of contact with the allergen, but sometimes it persists indefinitely, for example, chromate allergy. Prognosis depends on patient education and compliance in avoiding allergens and appropriate skin care.
Preventive Measure: It is important to recognize how you are in contact with the responsible substance so that, where possible, you can avoid it. Find out precisely what you are allergic to by having comprehensive patch tests. Identify where the allergen is found, thus read labels of all products before use. Carefully study your environment to locate the allergen. Note: many chemicals have several names, and cross-reactions to similar chemicals with different names are common. Wear appropriate gloves to protect hands from touching materials to which you react and remove gloves in the appropriate way. Some chemicals will penetrate certain gloves; seek a safety expert's advice. Ask your dermatologist to help.

Description: Alopecia areata is an autoimmune condition characterized by sudden, non-scarring hair loss in round or oval patches on the scalp, beard, eyebrows, or other areas of the body with hair. It results from immune cells attacking hair follicles.
Diagnosis: Diagnosis is primarily clinical, based on the characteristic appearance of well-demarcated bald patches. Trichoscopy, hair pull test, and occasionally skin biopsy may aid in diagnosis if needed.
Differential Diagnosis: Trichotillomania, temporal triangular alopecia, central centrifugal cicatricial alopecia, discoid lupus erythematosus affecting the scalp, tinea capitis, telogen effluvium, androgenetic alopecia, secondary syphilis, lichen planopilaris, frontal fibrosing alopecia.
Treatment: There is no cure for alopecia areata, but treatments aim to induce hair regrowth and manage psychological impact. Options include intralesional corticosteroid injections, topical corticosteroids, minoxidil, anthralin, topical immunotherapy, systemic corticosteroids, Janus kinase (JAK) inhibitors, and other less common therapies.
Demographics: Affects individuals of all skin and hair colors. Peak incidence in the second and third decades of life, with no significant sex or ethnic predominance.
Gender: No significant gender predominance.
Age Group: Onset typically occurs before the fourth decade, with peak incidence in the second and third decades.
Additional note: Alopecia areata can present in various patterns including patchy alopecia areata, alopecia totalis (complete scalp hair loss), alopecia universalis (complete body hair loss), and other less common variants.
Cause: Thought to involve genetic predisposition and autoimmune mechanisms where immune cells attack hair follicles.
Symptoms: Sudden onset of patchy hair loss, possible tingling or itching in affected areas (trichodynia), and changes in nail texture such as pitting or ridging in some cases.
Complications: Psychological distress, higher rates of depression and anxiety disorders, association with other autoimmune conditions like vitiligo and thyroid disease.
Outcomes: Spontaneous hair regrowth is possible but unpredictable. Response to treatment varies, and relapses are common. Progression to more extensive hair loss patterns occurs in a minority of cases.
Preventive Measure: Currently, there are no known preventive measures for alopecia areata.

Description: Amelanotic melanoma is a type of melanoma that lacks pigmentation, making it difficult to diagnose based on visual inspection alone. It can appear as a pink, red, or flesh-colored lesion.
Diagnosis: Diagnosis is challenging due to the lack of pigment. Dermoscopy and biopsy are essential for definitive diagnosis. Histopathological examination confirms the presence of melanoma cells.
Differential Diagnosis: Benign lesions: such as seborrheic keratosis or dermatofibroma, which can resemble amelanotic melanoma. Squamous cell carcinoma: may present as an ulcerated or crusted lesion. Basal cell carcinoma: often has a pearly or translucent appearance.
Treatment: Treatment involves surgical excision with adequate margins. Additional treatments may include lymph node biopsy, immunotherapy, targeted therapy, or chemotherapy depending on the stage and spread of the melanoma.
Demographics: Amelanotic melanoma can occur in individuals of all skin types, but fair-skinned individuals are at higher risk due to increased UV sensitivity and lower melanin production.
Gender: Affects both males and females.
Age Group: Most commonly diagnosed in adults, with the average age at diagnosis around 60 years old.
Additional note: Early detection is crucial as amelanotic melanoma can be more aggressive and diagnosed at a later stage compared to pigmented melanomas.
Cause: UV radiation exposure, genetic factors, and immunosuppression play a role in the development of melanoma. UV exposure is a significant risk factor, especially in fair-skinned individuals with a history of sunburns or excessive sun exposure.
Symptoms: Symptoms include a pink, red, or flesh-colored lesion that may be raised, ulcerated, or bleeding. The lesion may evolve and change over time, making monitoring for changes important.
Complications: Complications can include metastasis to lymph nodes or distant organs, which significantly worsens prognosis and survival rates.
Outcomes: Early-stage amelanotic melanomas have a better prognosis than advanced stages. Prognosis depends on the stage at diagnosis, with early detection leading to higher survival rates.
Preventive Measure: Preventive measures include sun protection strategies such as wearing sunscreen, protective clothing, and avoiding peak sun hours. Regular skin examinations and self-checks can aid in early detection.

Description: Angioedema is rapid swelling of the deeper layers of the skin, often affecting the face, lips, tongue, throat, or genitals. It can be caused by allergic reactions, medications, or genetic factors.
Diagnosis: Diagnosis is clinical, based on the characteristic rapid onset of swelling in the deeper layers of the skin or mucous membranes. Blood tests and allergy testing may be used to identify underlying causes such as allergies or genetic disorders.
Differential Diagnosis: Urticaria (hives): superficial swelling of the skin that is typically itchy and transient. Cellulitis: bacterial infection causing localized swelling, redness, and warmth. Hereditary angioedema: genetic condition causing recurrent episodes of angioedema without associated urticaria.
Treatment: Treatment depends on the underlying cause. Antihistamines, corticosteroids, and epinephrine may be used for allergic angioedema. For hereditary angioedema, specific medications targeting the underlying genetic defect are prescribed.
Demographics: Angioedema can occur in individuals of all ages and ethnicities. Allergic angioedema is more common in those with a history of allergies or atopy.
Gender: Affects both males and females equally.
Age Group: Can occur at any age, but allergic angioedema often presents in childhood or early adulthood, while hereditary angioedema may manifest later in life.
Additional note: Family history and recurrent episodes without associated urticaria may indicate hereditary angioedema. Allergic angioedema is often associated with allergic triggers such as foods, medications, or insect stings.
Cause: Allergic triggers (e.g., foods, medications, insect stings), genetic mutations affecting enzymes involved in regulating blood vessels, or medications can trigger angioedema.
Symptoms: Symptoms include rapid swelling of the deeper layers of the skin or mucous membranes, often painless but may cause discomfort or difficulty breathing if affecting the throat or tongue.
Complications: Complications can include airway obstruction if swelling affects the throat or tongue, which requires immediate medical attention. Recurrent episodes may impact quality of life and psychological well-being.
Outcomes: Prognosis depends on the underlying cause and response to treatment. Allergic angioedema typically resolves with avoidance of triggers and appropriate treatment. Hereditary angioedema requires lifelong management to prevent episodes and manage symptoms.
Preventive Measure: Preventive measures include avoiding known triggers, carrying epinephrine auto-injectors for severe allergic reactions, and genetic counseling for hereditary angioedema to understand familial risks and management options.

Description: Angular cheilitis is inflammation and fissuring at the corners of the mouth, often caused by fungal or bacterial infections, nutritional deficiencies, or mechanical factors.
Diagnosis: Diagnosis is clinical, based on the characteristic appearance of red, fissured lesions at the corners of the mouth. Microscopic examination or culture of skin scrapings may be used to identify fungal or bacterial pathogens.
Differential Diagnosis: Perioral dermatitis: rash around the mouth with papules and pustules. Contact dermatitis: rash or irritation due to contact with allergens or irritants. Herpes simplex virus: cold sores or lesions around the mouth that can cause pain and itching. Sjogren's syndrome: autoimmune condition causing dryness of the mouth and eyes, which can predispose to angular cheilitis.
Treatment: Treatment involves addressing the underlying cause. Topical antifungal or antibacterial creams may be prescribed for infectious angular cheilitis. Nutritional supplements may be recommended for deficiency-related angular cheilitis. Barrier creams and avoiding irritants can help prevent recurrence.
Demographics: Angular cheilitis can occur in individuals of all ages and backgrounds. It is more common in those with conditions that predispose to skin infections or nutritional deficiencies.
Gender: Affects both males and females equally.
Age Group: Can occur at any age, but is more common in older adults due to factors such as decreased immune function or denture use.
Cause: Common causes include fungal or bacterial infections (e.g., Candida albicans, Staphylococcus aureus), nutritional deficiencies (e.g., iron, vitamin B12), and mechanical factors (e.g., ill-fitting dentures, lip licking).
Symptoms: Symptoms include redness, swelling, and fissuring at the corners of the mouth, which may be painful or itchy. Lesions may crust, and secondary infections can occur.
Complications: Complications can include secondary bacterial infections, chronic inflammation, or discomfort when eating or speaking.
Outcomes: Prognosis is generally good with appropriate treatment. Addressing the underlying cause and maintaining good oral hygiene can prevent recurrence.
Preventive Measure: Preventive measures include maintaining good oral hygiene, addressing nutritional deficiencies, avoiding irritants, and treating underlying conditions that predispose to angular cheilitis.

Description: Annular lichenoid dermatitis of youth is a rare skin condition characterized by annular (ring-shaped), scaly patches typically affecting children and young adults.
Diagnosis: Diagnosis is clinical, based on the characteristic appearance of annular, scaly patches on the skin. Biopsy may be performed to confirm the diagnosis and rule out other conditions.
Differential Diagnosis: Pityriasis rosea: presents with similar annular lesions but typically has a larger, single herald patch followed by smaller patches. Nummular eczema: coin-shaped eczematous lesions that can resemble annular lichenoid dermatitis. Granuloma annulare: non-itchy, raised bumps or ring-shaped lesions on the skin.
Treatment: Treatment may include topical corticosteroids, antihistamines for symptomatic relief, and moisturizers to reduce dryness and itching. Phototherapy or systemic medications may be considered for severe or refractory cases.
Demographics: Annular lichenoid dermatitis of youth primarily affects children and young adults, with a higher prevalence in certain populations.
Gender: Affects both males and females equally.
Age Group: Most commonly affects children and young adults, typically under the age of 30 years old.
Cause: The condition may have an autoimmune or inflammatory basis, but the exact cause is unknown. It may be triggered by viral infections or environmental factors in susceptible individuals.
Symptoms: Symptoms include annular, scaly patches on the skin that may be itchy or asymptomatic. Lesions often appear on the trunk, arms, or legs and may resolve spontaneously over weeks to months.
Complications: Complications can include post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation or scarring in severe cases. Recurrence of lesions may occur in some individuals.
Outcomes: Prognosis is generally good, with most cases resolving spontaneously or responding well to treatment. However, recurrence of lesions may occur in some individuals.
Preventive Measure: Preventive measures include maintaining good skin hygiene, avoiding potential triggers such as excessive sun exposure or irritating skincare products, and promptly treating any viral infections.

Description: Anogenital warts are growths that appear in the genital and anal areas caused by certain strains of the human papillomavirus (HPV). They are a common sexually transmitted infection.
Diagnosis: Diagnosis is clinical, based on the characteristic appearance of warts in the anogenital region. HPV DNA testing and biopsy can confirm the diagnosis and identify the HPV strain.
Differential Diagnosis: Molluscum contagiosum: viral infection causing small, flesh-colored bumps. Condyloma lata: flat, moist lesions associated with secondary syphilis. Skin tags: benign growths that can resemble warts but are not caused by HPV.
Treatment: Treatment options include topical treatments such as imiquimod, podophyllin, or trichloroacetic acid. Cryotherapy, laser therapy, or surgical excision may be used for larger or resistant warts.
Demographics: Anogenital warts can occur in sexually active individuals of all ages, with a higher prevalence in young adults.
Gender: Affects both males and females equally.
Age Group: Can occur at any age but is most common in sexually active young adults.
Cause: Caused by certain strains of human papillomavirus (HPV), primarily HPV types 6 and 11, transmitted through sexual contact.
Symptoms: Symptoms include small, flesh-colored or gray growths in the genital or anal area. They may be single or multiple, raised or flat, and can cause itching or discomfort.
Complications: Complications can include recurrent infections, psychological distress, and an increased risk of cervical or anal cancer due to certain high-risk HPV strains.
Outcomes: Prognosis is generally good with treatment, but recurrence is common. Persistent infection with high-risk HPV strains can lead to cancer.
Preventive Measure: Preventive measures include HPV vaccination, practicing safe sex (using condoms), and regular medical check-ups for sexually active individuals.

Description: Aquagenic wrinkling of the palms is a condition where the skin on the palms wrinkles excessively upon exposure to water.
Diagnosis: Diagnosis is clinical, based on the characteristic appearance of the palms after water exposure. The water immersion test can confirm the diagnosis.
Differential Diagnosis: None
Treatment: Treatment may include avoiding prolonged water exposure and using emollients or barrier creams. In some cases, aluminum chloride antiperspirants or Botox injections may be used.
Demographics: Aquagenic wrinkling of the palms can occur in individuals of all ages and ethnicities.
Gender: Affects both males and females equally.
Age Group: Can occur at any age.
Additional note: The condition is often associated with cystic fibrosis or carriers of the cystic fibrosis gene. It may also occur in individuals without any underlying disease.
Cause: Prolonged exposure to water leads to the rapid formation of white, wrinkled plaques on the palms, often within minutes.
Symptoms: None
Complications: None
Outcomes: Prognosis is generally good, but the condition can be chronic and recurrent. Managing underlying conditions like cystic fibrosis can help control symptoms.
Preventive Measure: Preventive measures include minimizing water exposure and using protective hand creams to reduce wrinkling.

Description: Atopic dermatitis, also known as eczema, is a chronic inflammatory skin condition characterized by dry, itchy, and inflamed skin.
Diagnosis: Diagnosis is clinical, based on the characteristic appearance of eczematous lesions and patient history. Skin biopsy and allergy testing may help confirm the diagnosis.
Differential Diagnosis: Contact dermatitis: caused by allergens or irritants leading to similar lesions. Psoriasis: characterized by well-defined, scaly plaques, often with a silver scale. Seborrheic dermatitis: presents with greasy, scaly patches, often on the scalp and face.
Treatment: Treatment includes topical corticosteroids, emollients, and antihistamines for itch relief. Severe cases may require systemic treatments such as immunosuppressants or biologics. Avoiding triggers and maintaining skin hydration are key management strategies.
Demographics: Atopic dermatitis can occur in individuals of all ages and ethnicities, but is more common in those with a family history of atopy.
Gender: Affects both males and females equally.
Age Group: Most commonly affects infants and young children, but can persist or recur in adulthood.
Cause: The exact cause is unknown, but it is believed to involve a combination of genetic, environmental, and immunological factors.
Symptoms: Symptoms include dry, itchy, and inflamed skin, often with red to brownish-gray patches. Lesions can weep, crust, and become thickened and scaly over time.
Complications: Complications can include secondary bacterial or viral skin infections, sleep disturbances due to itching, and psychological distress.
Outcomes: Prognosis varies; while many children outgrow the condition, others may experience lifelong symptoms. Effective management can significantly improve quality of life.
Preventive Measure: Preventive measures include maintaining skin hydration, avoiding known triggers, and using gentle skin care products.

Description: Atopic hand dermatitis is a form of eczema that affects the hands, causing them to become dry, itchy, and inflamed.
Diagnosis: Diagnosis is clinical, based on the characteristic appearance of eczematous lesions on the hands and patient history. Patch testing may help identify allergens.
Differential Diagnosis: Contact dermatitis: caused by allergens or irritants, leading to similar lesions. Psoriasis: characterized by well-defined, scaly plaques, often with a silver scale. Dyshidrotic eczema: presents with small, itchy blisters on the sides of the fingers and palms.
Treatment: Treatment includes topical corticosteroids, emollients, and antihistamines for itch relief. Severe cases may require systemic treatments such as immunosuppressants or biologics. Avoiding triggers and maintaining skin hydration are key management strategies.
Demographics: Atopic hand dermatitis can occur in individuals of all ages and ethnicities, but is more common in those with a family history of atopy.
Gender: Affects both males and females equally.
Age Group: Can occur at any age, but is most common in adults who have a history of atopic dermatitis.
Cause: The exact cause is unknown, but it is believed to involve a combination of genetic, environmental, and immunological factors.
Symptoms: Symptoms include dry, itchy, and inflamed skin on the hands, often with red to brownish-gray patches. Lesions can weep, crust, and become thickened and scaly over time.
Complications: Complications can include secondary bacterial or viral skin infections, sleep disturbances due to itching, and psychological distress.
Outcomes: Prognosis varies; while many individuals may experience intermittent flare-ups, effective management can significantly improve quality of life.
Preventive Measure: Preventive measures include maintaining skin hydration, avoiding known triggers, and using gentle skin care products.

Description: Atypical fibroxanthoma is a rare, low-grade skin cancer that typically occurs in sun-damaged skin of elderly individuals.
Diagnosis: Diagnosis is clinical, supported by histopathological examination of a skin biopsy.
Differential Diagnosis: Squamous cell carcinoma: another type of skin cancer with similar presentation. Basal cell carcinoma: typically presents as pearly nodules, but can mimic atypical fibroxanthoma. Melanoma: can present with variable appearance, requiring biopsy for differentiation.
Treatment: Treatment typically involves surgical excision with clear margins. Mohs micrographic surgery may be used to ensure complete removal.
Demographics: Atypical fibroxanthoma primarily affects elderly individuals with a history of significant sun exposure.
Gender: More common in males.
Age Group: Typically affects elderly individuals, usually over the age of 60.
Cause: The exact cause is unknown, but risk factors include chronic sun exposure and a history of radiation therapy.
Symptoms: Symptoms include a rapidly growing, red, dome-shaped nodule, often on the head or neck.
Complications: Complications can include local recurrence if not completely excised. Rarely, metastasis can occur.
Outcomes: Prognosis is generally good with complete surgical excision. Regular follow-up is necessary to monitor for recurrence.
Preventive Measure: Preventive measures include avoiding excessive sun exposure, using sunscreen, and wearing protective clothing.

Description: Atypical mycobacterial infections are caused by non-tuberculous mycobacteria, leading to chronic skin and soft tissue infections.
Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves clinical examination, culture, and histopathological analysis of infected tissue. PCR may be used to identify the specific mycobacterial species.
Differential Diagnosis: Tuberculosis: caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, presenting with systemic symptoms. Fungal infections: can mimic the presentation of atypical mycobacterial infections. Bacterial abscesses: caused by common bacteria, leading to localized infection.
Treatment: Treatment typically involves prolonged courses of antibiotics, based on susceptibility testing. Surgical debridement may be necessary for severe or refractory cases.
Demographics: Atypical mycobacterial infections can occur in individuals of all ages and backgrounds, often affecting those with compromised immune systems.
Gender: Affects both males and females equally.
Age Group: Can occur at any age, but is more common in individuals with weakened immune systems or underlying chronic conditions.
Cause: Caused by non-tuberculous mycobacteria, such as Mycobacterium avium complex, Mycobacterium marinum, and others.
Symptoms: Symptoms include chronic, non-healing ulcers, nodules, or abscesses, often associated with drainage or sinus tract formation.
Complications: Complications can include chronic, recurrent infections, extensive tissue damage, and dissemination in immunocompromised individuals.
Outcomes: Prognosis depends on the severity of infection and response to treatment. Early diagnosis and appropriate therapy can lead to good outcomes.
Preventive Measure: Preventive measures include avoiding exposure to contaminated water or soil, and maintaining good skin hygiene, especially in individuals with compromised immune systems.

Description: Autonomic denervation dermatitis is a rare skin condition characterized by chronic inflammation due to loss of autonomic nerve function in the skin.
Diagnosis: Diagnosis is clinical, based on the characteristic presentation and history of autonomic nerve damage. Skin biopsy may be performed for confirmation.
Differential Diagnosis: None
Treatment: Treatment focuses on managing symptoms and underlying conditions. Topical corticosteroids and moisturizers may be used to reduce inflammation and dryness.
Demographics: Autonomic denervation dermatitis can occur in individuals with conditions that affect autonomic nerve function, such as diabetes or neurological disorders.
Gender: Affects both males and females equally.
Age Group: Can occur at any age, but is more common in adults with underlying conditions affecting autonomic nerve function.
Cause: The condition is caused by loss of autonomic nerve function in the skin, leading to chronic inflammation and impaired skin barrier function.
Symptoms: Symptoms include chronic inflammation, dryness, and itching of the skin. Lesions may appear as red, scaly patches.
Complications: Complications can include secondary bacterial or fungal infections due to impaired skin barrier function.
Outcomes: Prognosis varies depending on the underlying cause and effectiveness of symptom management. Chronic management may be necessary for individuals with persistent autonomic nerve dysfunction.
Preventive Measure: Preventive measures include managing underlying conditions that affect autonomic nerve function and maintaining good skin hygiene.

Description: Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is the most common type of skin cancer, arising from the basal cells in the epidermis. It typically occurs on sun-exposed areas of the skin.
Diagnosis: Diagnosis is clinical, supported by dermoscopy and confirmed by histopathological examination of a skin biopsy.
Differential Diagnosis: Squamous cell carcinoma: another common type of skin cancer with a similar presentation. Sebaceous hyperplasia: benign enlargement of sebaceous glands that can resemble BCC. Melanoma: requires differentiation via biopsy due to its potential for metastasis.
Treatment: Treatment typically involves surgical excision, Mohs micrographic surgery, or topical treatments such as imiquimod or 5-fluorouracil. Radiation therapy may be used in certain cases.
Demographics: Basal cell carcinoma primarily affects individuals with fair skin who have had significant sun exposure.
Gender: More common in males.
Age Group: Typically affects older adults, usually over the age of 50.
Cause: The primary cause is cumulative sun exposure, with risk factors including fair skin, a history of sunburns, and genetic predisposition.
Symptoms: Symptoms include pearly or waxy bumps, often with visible blood vessels. Lesions may ulcerate, bleed, and fail to heal.
Complications: Complications can include local tissue destruction and disfigurement if not treated. Metastasis is rare but can occur in advanced cases.
Outcomes: Prognosis is generally excellent with early detection and appropriate treatment. Regular follow-up is necessary to monitor for recurrence or new lesions.
Preventive Measure: Preventive measures include avoiding excessive sun exposure, using sunscreen, and wearing protective clothing.

Description: Becker naevus is a benign skin lesion characterized by hyperpigmentation and hypertrichosis, typically on the upper trunk or upper arm.
Diagnosis: Diagnosis is clinical, based on the characteristic appearance of the lesion. A skin biopsy may be performed to confirm the diagnosis.
Differential Diagnosis: Congenital melanocytic nevus: usually present at birth and may have a more homogenous pigmentation. Café-au-lait spots: typically lighter in color and lack hypertrichosis. Epidermal nevus: tends to have a more verrucous or wart-like appearance.
Treatment: Treatment is generally not required unless for cosmetic reasons. Laser hair removal and pigment reduction therapies may be considered.
Demographics: Becker naevus primarily affects individuals during adolescence or early adulthood.
Gender: More common in males.
Age Group: Typically appears during adolescence or early adulthood.
Cause: The exact cause is unknown, but it may involve androgen receptor sensitivity and genetic factors.
Symptoms: Symptoms include a well-demarcated, hyperpigmented patch with increased hair growth, usually on the upper trunk or upper arm.
Complications: Complications are rare, but Becker naevus can sometimes be associated with skeletal or muscular anomalies in the affected area.
Outcomes: The lesion is benign and does not require treatment. It may become more pronounced during puberty and stabilize thereafter.
Preventive Measure: Preventive measures are not necessary, as the condition is benign and non-progressive.

Description: Bed bugs are small, parasitic insects that feed on the blood of humans and animals, causing itchy bites and discomfort.
Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on the characteristic appearance of bites, usually in a linear or clustered pattern, and the presence of bed bugs or their signs in the living environment.
Differential Diagnosis: Flea bites: typically found on the lower legs and ankles and may have a central punctum. Mosquito bites: usually solitary and more random in distribution. Scabies: causes intense itching and a characteristic burrow appearance.
Treatment: Treatment includes antihistamines and topical corticosteroids to relieve itching and inflammation. Eradication of bed bugs from the living environment is essential.
Demographics: Bed bugs can affect individuals of all ages and socioeconomic backgrounds, particularly those living in shared or crowded accommodations.
Gender: Affects both males and females equally.
Age Group: Can occur at any age.
Cause: Bed bugs are caused by Cimex lectularius and Cimex hemipterus, which infest living spaces and feed on human blood at night.
Symptoms: Symptoms include itchy, red bites, often arranged in a linear or clustered pattern. Bites may develop into welts or blisters.
Complications: Complications can include secondary bacterial infections from scratching, and psychological distress from persistent infestations.
Outcomes: With effective eradication and symptomatic treatment, outcomes are generally good. However, reinfestation is possible without proper preventive measures.
Preventive Measure: Preventive measures include regular inspection of living areas, maintaining cleanliness, and using protective covers for mattresses and furniture.

Description: Behcet disease is a rare, chronic inflammatory disorder characterized by recurrent oral and genital ulcers, uveitis, and skin lesions.
Diagnosis: Diagnosis is clinical, based on the presence of recurrent oral ulcers plus at least two other criteria (genital ulcers, eye lesions, skin lesions, or a positive pathergy test).
Differential Diagnosis: Herpes simplex virus: causes painful oral and genital ulcers but usually has a viral prodrome. Systemic lupus erythematosus: can present with similar mucocutaneous and ocular manifestations. Inflammatory bowel disease: may have associated skin and mucosal involvement.
Treatment: Treatment involves immunosuppressive agents such as corticosteroids, azathioprine, and biologics to control inflammation. Symptomatic treatment for ulcers and eye involvement is also important.
Demographics: Behcet disease is most common in individuals of Mediterranean, Middle Eastern, and East Asian descent.
Gender: Affects both males and females, but tends to be more severe in males.
Age Group: Typically presents in young adults, between 20-40 years of age.
Cause: The exact cause is unknown, but it is believed to involve a combination of genetic predisposition and environmental triggers leading to an abnormal immune response.
Symptoms: Symptoms include recurrent, painful oral and genital ulcers, eye inflammation (uveitis), and various skin lesions such as erythema nodosum or acne-like lesions.
Complications: Complications can include blindness from uveitis, large vessel thrombosis, and neurological involvement leading to significant morbidity.
Outcomes: The disease course is chronic and relapsing, with periods of remission and flare-ups. Long-term management is required to control symptoms and prevent complications.
Preventive Measure: Preventive measures include avoiding known triggers, regular follow-up with healthcare providers, and adherence to treatment regimens to manage inflammation.

Description: Calcinosis cutis is characterized by the deposition of calcium salts in the skin and subcutaneous tissue.
Diagnosis: Diagnosis is clinical, supported by imaging studies such as X-rays and histopathological examination of biopsied tissue.
Differential Diagnosis: Scleroderma: may present with similar calcinosis but with additional skin thickening and other systemic features. Gout: characterized by deposition of uric acid crystals, typically affecting joints. Tumoral calcinosis: large, painless masses of calcium, usually around joints.
Treatment: Treatment options include surgical excision of large deposits, and medications such as diltiazem and bisphosphonates. Treating the underlying condition is also important.
Demographics: Calcinosis cutis can occur in individuals of all ages, but the demographics depend on the underlying cause, such as autoimmune diseases.
Gender: Affects both males and females.
Age Group: Can occur at any age, depending on the underlying condition.
Cause: Causes include dystrophic calcification from tissue damage, metastatic calcification from hypercalcemia, and idiopathic or iatrogenic causes.
Symptoms: Symptoms include hard, white or yellowish nodules or plaques in the skin, which may ulcerate and discharge chalky material.
Complications: Complications can include secondary infections, ulceration, and significant pain or discomfort.
Outcomes: The prognosis depends on the underlying cause and the extent of calcification. Management of the underlying disease can help improve outcomes.
Preventive Measure: Preventive measures include managing underlying conditions that predispose to calcification and monitoring for early signs of calcinosis.

Description: Catscratch disease is an infectious disease caused by the bacterium Bartonella henselae, typically transmitted through cat scratches or bites.
Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on clinical presentation, history of cat contact, and serologic testing for Bartonella henselae antibodies.
Differential Diagnosis: Lymphadenopathy: can occur with other infections or malignancies. Tularemia: another zoonotic infection with similar lymph node involvement. Toxoplasmosis: can cause lymphadenopathy, especially in immunocompromised individuals.
Treatment: Treatment is usually supportive, including analgesics and antipyretics. Antibiotics such as azithromycin may be used in severe cases or for immunocompromised patients.
Demographics: Catscratch disease primarily affects children and young adults who have contact with cats.
Gender: Affects both males and females equally.
Age Group: Most commonly affects children and young adults.
Cause: The cause is infection with Bartonella henselae, typically transmitted through cat scratches, bites, or flea bites.
Symptoms: Symptoms include a papule or pustule at the site of inoculation, followed by regional lymphadenopathy, fever, and malaise.
Complications: Complications can include suppurative lymphadenitis, hepatosplenic involvement, and in rare cases, neuroretinitis or encephalopathy.
Outcomes: The disease is usually self-limited, with most patients recovering without specific treatment. Severe cases may require antibiotic therapy.
Preventive Measure: Preventive measures include avoiding rough play with cats, especially kittens, and maintaining good hygiene and flea control for pets.

Description: Cholinergic urticaria is a type of physical urticaria triggered by heat, exercise, or stress, leading to itchy hives.
Diagnosis: Diagnosis is clinical, based on the characteristic appearance of small hives and their association with triggers. A challenge test involving exercise or a hot bath may be performed.
Differential Diagnosis: Exercise-induced anaphylaxis: a more severe reaction that includes systemic symptoms such as difficulty breathing. Chronic spontaneous urticaria: occurs without specific triggers and has a more persistent course. Heat rash: usually presents with fine, red papules and is more common in infants.
Treatment: Treatment includes antihistamines to control symptoms, and avoiding known triggers. Severe cases may require more aggressive treatment such as omalizumab.
Demographics: Cholinergic urticaria can affect individuals of all ages and ethnicities.
Gender: Affects both males and females equally.
Age Group: Can occur at any age, but is most common in adolescents and young adults.
Cause: The exact cause is unknown, but it is believed to involve an abnormal response to acetylcholine released during heat, exercise, or stress.
Symptoms: Symptoms include small, itchy hives that appear quickly after exposure to triggers such as heat, exercise, or emotional stress.
Complications: Complications can include significant discomfort and disruption of daily activities. Rarely, severe cases can lead to anaphylactic reactions.
Outcomes: The condition is chronic but manageable with avoidance of triggers and medication. Most individuals experience improvement over time.
Preventive Measure: Preventive measures include avoiding known triggers, taking antihistamines prophylactically, and maintaining a cool environment.

Description: Chronic actinic dermatitis is a persistent, photosensitive dermatitis characterized by eczematous lesions on sun-exposed areas.
Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on clinical presentation, phototesting, and skin biopsy. Patch testing may be used to identify specific allergens.
Differential Diagnosis: Polymorphous light eruption: presents with pruritic papules or plaques after sun exposure but usually has a seasonal pattern. Contact dermatitis: may present similarly but without strict sun-exposed distribution. Lupus erythematosus: can cause photosensitivity with similar cutaneous manifestations but has systemic features.
Treatment: Treatment includes broad-spectrum sunscreens, topical corticosteroids, and systemic immunosuppressants such as azathioprine or cyclosporine.
Demographics: Chronic actinic dermatitis primarily affects older males, especially those with outdoor occupations.
Gender: More common in males.
Age Group: Typically presents in middle-aged to older adults.
Additional note: Patients may have a history of atopic dermatitis or chronic eczema.
Cause: The exact cause is unknown but involves abnormal immune responses to sunlight and possibly allergens.
Symptoms: Symptoms include pruritic, eczematous plaques on sun-exposed areas such as the face, neck, and hands.
Complications: Complications can include chronic lichenification and secondary bacterial infections.
Outcomes: The condition is chronic and relapsing, requiring long-term management of symptoms and sun protection.
Preventive Measure: Preventive measures include strict sun protection, avoidance of identified allergens, and use of protective clothing.
